sub_topic: Determining the rank of a matrix
message_1:
Consider the matrix A = 
\begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 4 & 6 \\
    -1 & -2 & -3 \\
    3 & 6 & 9
\end{bmatrix}

Determine the rank of matrix A using elementary row operations.
message_2:
To determine the rank of matrix A, we will perform elementary row operations to get it into its row-echelon form. 

Matrix A:
\begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 4 & 6 \\
    -1 & -2 & -3 \\
    3 & 6 & 9
\end{bmatrix}

Step 1: Add half of row 1 to row 2 to eliminate the -1 in the second row.
New matrix:
\begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 4 & 6 \\
    0 & 0 & 0 \\
    3 & 6 & 9
\end{bmatrix}

Step 2: Subtract 1.5 times row 1 from row 3 to eliminate the 3 in the third row.
New matrix:
\begin{bmatrix}
    2 & 4 & 6 \\
    0 & 0 & 0 \\
    0 & 0 & 0
\end{bmatrix}

Now the matrix is in row-echelon form. The rank of a matrix is the number of non-zero rows in its row-echelon form. In this case, there is only 1 non-zero row.

Therefore, the rank of matrix A is 1.
